body:
Current work on this can be viewed in the following feature branch.

https://github.com/junit-team/junit-framework/compare/main...sbrannen:junit-framework:issues/4815-CharSequence-support-in-fallback-conversion

issue.title: Support `CharSequence` argument for Fallback String-to-Object Conversion

repository.name: junit-framework
repository.description: âœ… The programmer-friendly testing framework for Java and the JVM

issue.body:
Prior to this commit, the ["Fallback String-to-Object Conversion"](https://docs.junit.org/current/user-guide/#writing-tests-parameterized-tests-argument-conversion-implicit-fallback) support for parameterized tests supported factory constructors and methods that accepted a single `String` argument.

This commit relaxes that restriction to support factory constructors and methods that accept either a single `String` argument or a single `CharSequence` argument, since the original source `String` can always be supplied to an `Executable` that accepts a `CharSequence`.

Note that this change is available to third parties via `ConversionSupport` in `junit-platform-commons`, which `junit-jupiter-params` utilizes.

- Closes #4815

body: FYI: I've opened PR #4819 for discussion and review.

rename.from: Extend fallback conversion to support CharSequence
rename.to: Extend fallback conversion to support `CharSequence` factory arguments

issue.title: Implicit conversion should avoid `@Deprecated` methods

type.name: Feature
type.description: A request, idea, or new functionality

repository.name: junit-framework
repository.description: âœ… The programmer-friendly testing framework for Java and the JVM

issue.body:
[Implicit conversion fallback](https://docs.junit.org/current/user-guide/#writing-tests-parameterized-tests-argument-conversion-implicit-fallback) allows JUnit to convert a `String` to an arbitrary `Object`. It does this by [searching](https://github.com/junit-team/junit-framework/issues/1231) for a constructor or factory method taking one `String` (with a further fallback to look for `CharSequence` [added later](https://github.com/junit-team/junit-framework/issues/4815)).

This approach recently caused a problem for me. In a piece of shared code there was a factory method named `parseString` which I wanted to rename to the more standard `parse`. I did this by copying the method and marking `parseString` as deprecated (for removal). I didn't expect this to cause any issues, as it is a standard approach to refactoring a change like this from a shared code library. In the downstream code, someone was using the type via JUnit implicit argument conversion, and the test failed because JUnit now saw the class had 2 static factory methods where previously there was 1.

I'd like to propose a tweak to the algorithm.

1. Find all factory methods with a single `String` parameter, if there is only one, then use it
2. Find all factory methods with a single `CharSequence` parameter, if there is only one, then use it
3. (new step) Repeat step 1, removing any method marked as deprecated, if only one method then use it
4. (new step) Repeat step 2, removing any method marked as deprecated, if only one method then use it.

I believe this approach is backwards compatible, and would be a good enhancement. Thanks for your consideration.
